body:
Add two macros working on virtual names that can detect cubes vs grids.  Also, use _n_bands_ to help detect cubes vs grids.
Now works in Julia again.  Closes #6617.

comments_content.body: Before I submitted this PR, I ran all the CLI tests to make sure it worked.  However, I typically do not build and test if pyGMT (@seisman) and GMT.jl (@joa-quim.  or GMT/MEX for that matter) is affected - such as this one.  How difficult would it be for me to run all the tests in pyGMT and GMT.jl.  I have both repos installed?  Is there something equally simple to what we have for the CLI to run your tests?

> How difficult would it be for me to run all the tests in pyGMT and GMT.jl.

If you have the conda environment setup, then you should be able to run the full tests by typing `make test`. However, you would see ~50 failing tests due to some tiny changes between GMT 6.3.0 and dev.

Thanks, I will give it a try.  This also reminds me of this potential solution to the changing grids:

We do have test.generic-mapping-tools.org and we could simply keep the current set of files needed there with a limited gmt_data_server.txt and let gmtest.in select the test server.  As the regular data server gets updated the test server directory stays the same.  Apart from fixing any remaining old-data failures, going forward we should not have to worry.  If we need additional tiles or data for testing then we just place a copy in the test directory as well and it will be "frozen".

> We do have test.generic-mapping-tools.org and we could simply keep the current set of files needed there with a limited gmt_data_server.txt and let gmtest.in select the test server. As the regular data server gets updated the test server directory stays the same. Apart from fixing any remaining old-data failures, going forward we should not have to worry. If we need additional tiles or data for testing then we just place a copy in the test directory as well and it will be "frozen".

It sounds a good idea, but we already have `test.generic-mapping-tools.org` used for testing new versions of earth grid data, so perhaps we need a separate domain (and a separate folder on the server) instead.

I added GMT#master and using GMT and then tried the test.  I will add the output below but one thing I noticed that is odd is this:

```
You don't seem to have GMT installed and the automatic installation also failed.
You will have to do it yourself.
Install GMT with Homebrew: brew install gmt ghostscript ffmpeg
```

I am able to run debugs etc via GMT_LIBRARY so what does this mean?  Anyway, it looks like it tried to run the tests since I got various GMT messages.  Let me know if there are things here that puzzles you or we should have a look at since this is the first time the tests have been run on macOS possibly:

OK. reinstalled miniconda for arm and got further this time.  Perhaps @seisman can help with this: 

```
cd tmp-test-dir-with-unique-name; PYGMT_USE_EXTERNAL_DISPLAY="false" pytest --cov=pygmt --cov-config=../pyproject.toml --cov-report=term-missing --cov-report=xml --cov-report=html --pyargs  --doctest-plus pygmt
/bin/sh: pytest: command not found
make: *** [test] Error 127
```

> OK. reinstalled miniconda for arm and got further this time. Perhaps @seisman can help with this:
> 
> ```
> cd tmp-test-dir-with-unique-name; PYGMT_USE_EXTERNAL_DISPLAY="false" pytest --cov=pygmt --cov-config=../pyproject.toml --cov-report=term-missing --cov-report=xml --cov-report=html --pyargs  --doctest-plus pygmt
> /bin/sh: pytest: command not found
> make: *** [test] Error 127
> ```

You can change into your `pygmt` directory, open the `environment.yml` file and remove `gmt=6.3.0` at line 8, because you want to use your local GMT dev version. 

1. Run the following command to install required packages in an isolated environment (the environment is called `pygmt`):
```
conda env create -f environment.yml
```

2. Activate the environment:
```
conda activate pygmt
```

3. Install PyGMT in the environment:
```
make install
```

4. Run the tests:
```
make test
```

I had already activated pygmt so got this:

```
conda env create -f environment.yml

CondaValueError: prefix already exists: /Users/pwessel/miniconda3/envs/pygmt
```

How to undo my activation and rerun taht one?

Do this first:
```
conda deactivate
conda remove --name pygmt --all
```

OK done, but

```
conda env create -f environment.yml
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done
Solving environment: failed

ResolvePackageNotFound: 
  - dvc

```
It should be available in conda-forge. Can you try `conda config --add channels conda-forge` before run `conda env create -f environment.yml`?
Had already done that per debug instructions.  I think I installed it via pip in the past (for use with CLI GMT testing).
Maybe you can remove `dvc` from `environment.yml`.
OK, installing now.  Will test when done.

> You don't seem to have GMT installed and the automatic installation also failed.

The Julia tests are too verbose but I can't find a way of making more silent. The above is confusing because what is tested is the code that prints that message. So the test worked well because that message was printed. Same happens with several other printed messages where I'm testing the conditions that lead to those messages printings.

But you have 3 real failures. One is because you don't seem to have ``earthtide`` and the other two are strange. 

```
Expression: (GMT.parse_J(Dict(:J => (name = :albers, center = [10 20], parallels = [45 65])), "", "", false))[1] == " -JB10/20/45/65"
   Evaluated: " -JB20/3.39519326554e-313/45/65" == " -JB10/20/45/65"

...

Expression: (GMT.parse_R(Dict(:region_llur => (1, 2, 3, 4)), ""))[1] == " -R1/3/2/4+r"
   Evaluated: " -R4/3.01554413563416e-314/5.21501763667823e-310/5.21501984560147e-310+r" == " -R1/3/2/4+r"
```

Can't see why this only happens to you (The Mac CI tests parse these fine).

Thanks, test all ran; got 

`================== 192 failed, 363 passed, 2 skipped, 2 xfailed, 2 xpassed, 27 warnings in 66.25s (0:01:06) ===================`

and one tiny pdf plot opened up - possibly a test with a show?

My xbuild directory in fact does not have a supplemental.so.  But I have debugged supplements (a lot) but there are always issues: e.g., if I make changes to a supplement and run debug again it does not rebuild those modules and hence it is all bonkers in debugging.  I have to rebuild the entire thing (slow) and start again.  Painful - so getting motivated to switch to VSC.

> Thanks, test all ran; got
> 
> `================== 192 failed, 363 passed, 2 skipped, 2 xfailed, 2 xpassed, 27 warnings in 66.25s (0:01:06) ===================`
> 
> and one tiny pdf plot opened up - possibly a test with a show?

You need to run `dvc pull` first to download the baseline images, then the failures will be reduced to ~60.
Nevermind about Xcode and supplements.so - it is built. And earthtide is in it.

That message is printed when
```
	# Make sure this is a valid module
	if ((status = GMT_Call_Module(G_API[1], g_module, GMT_MODULE_EXIST, C_NULL)) != 0)
		error("GMT: No module by that name -- " * g_module * " -- was found.")
	end
```
so the ``earthtide`` module was not found by GMT.

And, apparently you don't et this (that runs only Julia code, no GMT calls)?

```
GMT.parse_J(Dict(:J => (name = :albers, center = [10 20], parallels = [45 65])), "", "", false)[1]
" -JB10/20/45/65"
```
Maybe some fun M1 Apple Silicon and Julia issues?

So it's shifting the *lon/lat*. It puts *lat* in place of *lon* and trash in place of *lon*. 
Does it make any difference if using vectors instead of matrices? I.e
```
GMT.parse_J(Dict(:J => (name = :albers, center = [10, 20], parallels = [45, 65])), "", "", false)[1]
```
No, same.
So this is the same problem as the ``parse_J``. For some forgotten reason I'm calling directly the C lib to do ``sprintf`` and it calls the ``asprintf`` function that is screwing in the M1.

title: Improve detection of cubes
